abstract.p: Letter from Amy Saland on prenatal testing she has chosen to have, and tests she will not have, during her pregnancy (May 9 article)

block.p: I had my first child at age 36 and was pleased with my ultrasounds and all of the blood tests results. I opted to skip the amniocentesis. Now, at age 39 and pregnant with my second, I am delighted with the opportunity to participate in the clinical trial for the ultrasound and blood test done in the first trimester.
Even though the amniocentesis is recommended based upon my age, I am choosing to take every noninvasive test available.

I had my first child at age 36 and was pleased with my ultrasounds and all of the blood tests results. I opted to skip the amniocentesis. Now, at age 39 and pregnant with my second, I am delighted with the opportunity to participate in the clinical trial for the ultrasound and blood test done in the first trimester.
Even though the amniocentesis is recommended based upon my age, I am choosing to take every noninvasive test available.
Although I know this goes against the current medical standards, I don't think that the amniocentesis would change anything since my husband and I both want to have this baby.
I think it is wonderful that we have so many available options and that we have the freedom to choose among them.
